comments:
The focus of Management 104 is the economic and institutional constraints on organizations in the formulation and implementation of human resources management policies and strategies in the United States and, as appropriate, internationally. The specific constraints discussed are labor markets (external and internal), labor laws (governing employment policies and employee relations), and labor unions (and the threat thereof). Particular attention is paid to the relationship of these constraints to the competitiveness of American enterprise in the global economy.

Students have a choice between MGMT104 and INSR205 to fulfill Wharton’s “Organizational Environment Requirement,” and while some students questioned how “such an unessential subject” found its way into the required curriculum, others found the class “useful and practical” for understanding behavior. “Extensive emphasis on research material” supplements the course, which was enjoyable for some, but was considered to be too much by others. Students reported that the material wasn’t integrated smoothly into the class, describing the structure as “disjointed,” “haphazard,” and “unorganized”.

Students were somewhat upset that “Professor Barankay has the answer he wants to hear in mind” and “cuts students off” or “tells them they are flat-out wrong” if they don’t provide the answer he has in mind. This factor diminished the participation element of the class. Other students pointed out some redeeming qualities of Professor Barankay, including his “accessibility” and “great feedback”.

The class has an important group component which was well-received. Groups meet during class to solve problems while the Professor walks around offering assistance. Some students complained that expectations regarding grades were not clear.
